instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with corrosion on <CHIP>U5620</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C9580</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C9581</CAPACITOR>. Additionally, there is a burn mark between RX2- and VBUS on the USB-C connector with a diode reading of 0.127 between the pins when the power jack board is disconnected.

The board draws 5.18V @ 46mA with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 0V and a diode reading of 0.001 to ground.

We have quite long shipping times where I come from so, I would like to debug as much as possible and then order all likely defective parts. Are there any components that usually fail together with <CHIP>U5620</CHIP>. Anything I can test regarding the short on the USB-C connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

This project is hopeless.

<CHIP>U5260</CHIP> is not the big problem here.
Liquid around <CAPACITOR>C9580</CAPACITOR>/81 could mean leakage occured from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to SSD,through <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>.

You have a pure short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; still same after removing <CAPACITOR>C9580</CAPACITOR>/81?
If yes, check resistance to ground on all big coils; including L9580/81.

USB-C connector is not interesting, until you eliminate the short from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
The connector must be changed; if you finally get the board booting (very unlikely).
